Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Story: I was stacking bricks when the shrill site alarm cut through the afternoon air. My heart jumped—protocol was clear: drop everything, head to the muster point, no exceptions. But just as I reached for my helmet, my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was a message from Mom: “Can you call? Dad’s not himself today.” I knew what she needed—just a few words, a check-in, a reminder that I cared. I’d promised myself I’d always be there for them, especially when things felt shaky at home. But the foreman’s voice was already echoing across the yard, urging us to move, and I could see the other workers streaming toward the gate. My hands shook as I weighed the phone in my palm, torn between the duty to my team and the promise I’d made to my family. The pressure built in my chest, the world narrowing to the choice I had to make, right now.
